Table 3 Entry Catalyst Cglucose SHMF YHMF 1 Nb-SBA-15-80 77.0 51.9 40.1 2 Nb-SBA-15-40 93.5 65.8 61.5 3 Nb-SBA-15-20 95.0 56.9 54.1 4 Nb-SBA-15-10 97.8 51.4 50.3 5 Nb2O5/SBA-15 55.1 29.5 16.3 Reaction conditions: 0.1g catalysts, 0.1g glucose, water saturated with NaCl (2ml), THF (6ml), 165°C, 3h. Research Paper Hydrothermally stable Nb-SBA-15 catalysts applied in carbohydrate conversion to 5-hydroxymethyl furfural Kaihao Peng Xiangcheng Li Xiaohui Liu ⁎ Yanqin Wang Shanghai Key Laboratory of Functional Materials Chemistry, Research Institute of Industrial Catalysis, School of Chemistry and Molecular Engineering, East China University of Science and Technology, Shanghai, 200237, PR China Shanghai Key Laboratory of Functional Materials Chemistry Research Institute of Industrial Catalysis School of Chemistry and Molecular Engineering East China University of Science and Technology Shanghai 200237 PR China ⁎ Corresponding author. Graphical abstract 5-hydroxymethyl furfural (HMF) is a bio-based platform chemical with high potential. The as-synthesized Nb-SBA-15 catalysts with mesoporous structures showed high catalytic performance for the conversion of carbohydrates to HMF in a “one-pot” process using biphasic conditions of THF/H2O-NaCl as the solvents. Nb-SBA-15 catalysts with different Si/Nb ratios were characterized by analytical techniques such as XRD, elemental analysis, SEM, TEM, N2 adsorption, NH3-TPD UV–vis DRS, Raman and Pyridine-FTIR. It was found that the acidity of Nb-SBA-15 catalysts could be tuned by modifying addition amount of niobium. The effects of reaction conditions, including temperature, time, and catalyst loading, on the conversions of carbohydrates and the yields of HMF were also investigated. The studies showed that Nb-SBA-15-40 catalysts which Si/Nb ratio is 40 gave the best yields of HMF due that Nb-SBA-15-40 had more niobium species in the SBA-15 silica framework and the mononuclear tetrahedral NbO4. Under the optimized conditions, the yield of HMF could reach 61.8% at 93.5% glucose conversion and 50.7% at 94.0% cellulose conversion, respectively. Moreover, its catalytic performance was largely retained after 10 recycles in glucose conversion reaction vindicating its good catalytic stability. Keywords 5-hydroxymethyl furfural Nb-SBA-15 Carbohydrate Dehydration Introduction It is well accepted that present petroleum based chemicals need to be replaced with renewable resources because of a rapidly rising global population and the dwindling reserves of petroleum based chemicals [1–4]. Therefore, effective utilization of renewable bio-based resources for the production of platform chemicals is ineluctable and necessary. One of the most important productions from carbohydrate is 5-hydroxymethyfurfural (HMF) that is a bio-based platform chemical with high potential [5–7]. HMF serves as a promising candidate to achieve a wide variety of high value-added intermediates (e.g., dihydroxymethylfuran [8], dimethyl furan [9] and levulinic acid [10]). Based on the previous research [11], it is found that the process of converting glucose to HMF includes tandem steps (Fig. 1 ). The first step of glucose isomerization is catalyzed in the presence of bases, enzymes, or Lewis acids. Brønsted acids drive the second step of fructose dehydration to HMF. Up to now, various catalysts have been developed for the production of HMF from dehydration of glucose, which can be divided into two categories: homogenous catalyst and heterogeneous catalyst. Homogenous catalysts include ionic liquids [12], lanthanide salts in ionic liquids [13] and metallic salts with mineral acids [14]. It is well-known that the disadvantages of homogenous catalysts include the equipment of corrosion, catalyst waste and difficult separation operations. And ionic liquids are expensive. Therefore, their replacement by heterogeneous catalysts especially solid acids is highly recommended owing to their environmentally friendly character, the easier catalyst recyclability, and product separation and recovery steps. Lu et al. [15] synthesized partially hydroxylated AlF3 using a sol-gel method. This catalyst could get 95.5% of glucose conversion and 57.3% of the optimized yield of HMF within 10h at 140°C. But catalyst recycling could not perform well. Only in three runs, HMF yield and glucose conversion decreased from 57.3% to 45.6% and 95.5% to 89.3%, respectively. Jimenez-Morales et al. [16] prepared Al-MCM-41 catalyst by a sol-gel method with n-dodecylammonium chloride as the template. It exhibited excellent activity in the dehydration of glucose to HMF in a biphasic condition of MIBK/H2O (98% of glucose conversion and 63% of HMF yield). However, the catalyst activity decreased with three runs (glucose conversion from 98% to 88%, HMF yield from 63% to 45%). It can be seen that the reported catalysts are hard to keep excellent hydrothermal stability. Therefore, it is highly demanded to develop a hydrothermal stable catalyst that can be used for the conversion of carbohydrate to HMF with multiple times. Niobic acid is a well-known water-tolerant solid acid as a potential solid acid candidate in water [17–20]. It is a very promising catalyst for dehydration of glucose in THF/H2O biphasic reaction system [21]. Zhang et al. [22] found that mesoporous niobium phosphate exhibited high activity in the dehydration of glucose to HMF in biphasic phase which gave 68.1% glucose conversion with 33.2% HMF yield at 160°C. Based on these, we designed a niobium-based mesoporous material which was used as the more efficient and environmental friendly catalysts for the production of HMF. This catalyst not only has good hydrothermal stability but also moderate acidity and good pore structure [23]. Among many kinds of mesoporous materials, ordered mesoporous material of SBA-15 which has a hexagonal pore structure has received much attention in the past decades [24,25]. This could owe to unique nature of SBA-15 which has a large pore channel network with easy and direct access for substrate and product. Thus the unique structure of SBA-15 could promote the inclusion or diffusion throughout the pore channels without pore blockage. Such properties spur the prospective utilization as catalysts and adsorbents [26–28]. On the other hand, niobium-based materials have been widely applied in catalyzing various types of reactions such as oxidation, dehydration, epoxidation [29–31]. Modification of the mesoporous silica by niobium leads to formation of Nb-containing mesoporous silica with isolated and tetrahedral coordinated Nb-oxide species [32,33]. Visualizing the above mentioned superior nature of SBA-15, we explored Nb incorporated SBA-15 for the dehydration of glucose to HMF in biphasic system of THF/H2O-NaCl. Nb was incorporated into SBA-15 by a conventional hydrothermal synthesis. The acidity of Nb-SBA-15 was tuned by incorporating different Nb levels in the samples to study the acidity effect on the reaction. Detailed characterization of the synthesized materials was investigated in the reaction of glucose in biphasic system to find the optimal catalysis conditions. We also studied various process parameters to achieve the best dehydration reaction conditions. Experimental section Chemicals 5-Hydroxymethylfurfural (HMF) was purchased from Alfa Aesar Chemical Reagent Company and cellulose from Fluka Analytical Co. Ltd., Niobium tartrate as precursor was home-made according to the literature [22,34]. The other chemicals were purchased from Sinopharm Chemical Reagent Co. Ltd. All purchased chemicals were analytical grade and used without further purification. Material preparation In a typical synthesis process [35,36], 2.0g of P123 was dissolved in 50ml of 1M HCl aqueous solution at 35°C. When P123 was dissolved completely, 4.5g of tetraethyl orthosilicate (TEOS, 98%) was added with stirring. The resulting mixture was stirred for 6h at 35°C. Then, a required amount of niobium tartrate dissolved in 30ml of 1M HCl aqueous solution was added to the pre-hydrolyzed silicate sol. After further stirring for 24h at 35°C, the mixture was transferred into a Teflon-lined autoclave for crystallization at 100°C for 3days. The products were filtered with washing by deionized water and ethanol, dried at 100°C overnight and calcined in air at 550°C for 5h with a ramp rate of 2°C/min to remove the template. By varying the amount of niobium tartrate, a series of Nb-SBA-15-n (n indicates the molar ratio of Si/Nb) catalysts were prepared. As comparison, Nb2O5/SBA-15 (the molar ratio of Si/Nb is 40) was prepared by impregnation method. Characterization Low-angle X-ray diffraction patterns were collected in the 2θ range 0.5–5°, with a Philips X′pert Pro diffractometer using Ni filtered CuKα radiation (k=1.5406Å, 40kV, 30mA), at a scan rate of 0.5°min−1. Nitrogen adsorption-desorption isotherms of the catalysts were measured at −196°C on a Micromeritics ASAP 2020M sorption analyzer. Prior to the measurements, the samples were heated in a vacuum at 373K for 8h to remove moisture and volatile impurities. The surface area was calculated by Brunauer–Emmett–Teller (BET) method on basis of the desorption data. The pore size distribution was calculated by Barrett–Joyner–Halanda (BJH) method. The total pore volume (Vt) was estimated at a relative pressure of 0.95. Scanning electronic microscopy (SEM) images were obtained from JEOL JSM-63602V and Hitachi S-3400N microscopes operated at 5kV or 15kV, respectively. Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) images were captured using a FEI Tecnai G2 F20 S-TWIN instrument at 200kV. The actual niobium concentration in the samples was determined using the ICP-AES instrument by digesting in a HF and H2SO4 mixture. Ammonia temperature-programmed-desorption (NH3-TPD) was carried out in a PX200 apparatus (Tianjin Golden Eagle Technology Limited Corporation) equipped with a thermal conductivity detector (TCD). About 50mg of the sample was heated at 550°C for 1h in N2 flow (40mlmin−1) to remove adsorbed water. When cooling down to 90°C, ammonia was saturated followed by N2 (40mlmin−1) purge for 1h. The samples were then heated to 500°C with a rate of 10°Cmin−1 and the amount of desorbed ammonia was detected by using a thermal conductivity detector (TCD) at 110°C [22]. UV–vis diffuse reflectance spectra (UV-vis DRS) were measured with a Perkin-Elmer Lambda 950 spectrometer equipped with a Praying-Mantis diffuse reflectance attachment. BaSO4 was used as a reference. Raman spectra of samples were collected on a Raman microscope (LabRAM HR, Horiba J.Y.) equipped with a deeply depleted thermoelectrically cooled CCD array detector and a high-grade Leica microscope (long working distance objective 50×). A visible 514nm argon ion laser with 10mW was used for an excitation. Infrared (IR) spectra of the pyridine adsorption were recorded on a Nicolet NEXUS 670 FT-IR spectrometer, with 32 scans at an effective resolution of 4cm−1. 50mg of a sample was pressed into a self-supporting wafer. The disc was mounted in a quartz IR cell equipped with a CaF2 window and a vacuum system. Prior to adsorption, the samples were pretreated at 400°C under vacuum, then cooled to 50°C when pyridine vapor was introduced into the cell. The samples were heated in vacuum at 100°C, 200°C and 400°C, respectively and spectra were recorded at room temperature. The quantification of acid sites was performed using the same expressions as those in the article of Rocha et al. [37,38]: C L = K L A 1450 = π IMEC L ( r 2 w ) A 1450 C B = K B A 1540 = π IMEC B ( r 2 w ) A 1540 CL and CB are the concentrations of Lewis acid sites and Brønsted acid sites; A1450 and A1540 are the integrated areas of bands at 1450 and 1540cm−1 in the original data of FTIR spectra, as shown in the Results and discussion section. KL and KB are molar extinction constants for Lewis and Brønsted acid sites; IMECL and IMECB are integration molar extinction coefficients, 2.22 and 1.67cm μmol−1 for Lewis and Brønsted acids, respectively; r is the wafer radius and w is the wafer weight of the self-supporting catalyst disk. Reaction procedure and products analysis All the dehydration reaction was carried out in a batch-type Teflon-lined stainless-steel autoclave (30ml), equipped with an internal thermo-controller and a pressure gauge. In a typical catalytic experiment, 0.10g of catalysts, 0.10g of carbohydrate and solvent (6ml THF and 2ml H2O saturated with NaCl) added to a stirred autoclave reactor. 0.5MPaN2 gas was used for purging air outside the reactor and keeping the solvent in the liquid phase. Here, the presence of NaCl can increase the partition coefficient of HMF in biphasic systems, which increasesthe HMF selectivity by removing it more efficiently from the reactive aqueous solution. NaCl is also useful in creating biphasic systems with solvents that are otherwise completely miscible with water, as well as increasing the upper critical solubility temperature of certain partially soluble solvents [39]. It takes 20 mins to heat the reactor from room temperature to the desired temperature (e.g. 165°C). In order to ensure the consistency of each experiment, when the rector was raised to the desired temperature, the zero time was recorded. After reaction, the autoclave was cooled to room temperature by loading cooling water. Then, the autoclave was opened, the catalyst was collected by filtration, and the supernatant liquid in the centrifugation tube was taken for analysis [40]. The analysis of HMF was carried out by means of an HPLC apparatus (Agilent 1200 Series) equipped with an XDB-C18 column (Eclipse USA) and quantified with an ultraviolet detector (Agilent G1314B) at 254nm based on the external standard. The eluent with a flow rate of 0.6mlmin−1 was a mixture of methanol and water with volumetric ratio of 20:80. Glucose was analyzed by HPLC (Agilent 1200 series, Bio-Rad Aminex HPX-87H column, 300mm×7.8mm×9μm). A 0.004M H2SO4 mobile phase was employed as the mobile phase at 55°C with a flow rate of 0.45mlmin−1. Only HMF and a little levulinc acid are detected in the reaction solution by the analysis GC–MS and HPLC. The yield of levulinc acid is about 0.1% and it is not given in the corresponding results anymore. Conversion of glucose and yield of HMF were defined as follows: Glucose conversion = moles of glucose reacted moles of starting glucose HMF yield = moles of HMF produced moles of staring glucose For cellulose (i.e. (C6H10O5)n, n≈220), cellulose conversion and the yield of HMF were defined as follows: A quantitative method using weight loss method has been developed to determine the quantity of cellulose after a catalytic reaction, which was used to calculate cellulose conversion. Cellulose conversion = C M ( b ) − C M ( a ) C M ( b ) HMF yield = moles of HMF produced moles of hexose units in cellulose where CM (b) is the dry solid including cellulose and catalyst before the catalytic reaction; CM (a) is the dry solid including cellulose and catalyst after catalytic reaction, washing and drying; hexose unit is C6H10O5 and the moles of hexose units in cellulose is obtained by dividing the mass of cellulose by the molecular weight of the hexose unit. Results and discussion X-ray diffraction The structure of the Nb-SBA-15 (Si/Nb=10, 20, 40, 80) materials were analyzed by powder XRD and the results are shown in Fig. 2 . It could be seen from Fig. 2 that all the Nb-SBA-15 samples exhibited three typical diffraction peaks in the 2θ range of 0.5–4.0° as SBA-15, which included one strong (100) reflection and two weak (110), (200) reflections.It is clear that the peaks all shifted to lower 2θ with increasing Nb contents of the samples. This is attributed to an increase in the unit cell parameter (a0) (seen from Table 1 ) caused by incorporation of Nb ions with larger ionic radius in the SBA-15 framework. N2 adsorption-desorption isotherm The N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms and pore size distributions of the Nb-SBA-15 samples with different Nb contents were measured and presented in Fig. 3 . All Nb-SBA-15 samples exhibited Type IV behavior with a sharp inflexion at P/P0 value between 0.7 and 0.8, which is attributed to capillary condensation within uniform pores. The H1 hysteresis loop, average pore diameter progressively diminishing at higher Nb loadings, was observed for all Nb-SBA-15 samples. The Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) surface area, average pore diameter and pore volumes of these samples are listed in Table 1. The BET specific surface area and total pore volume significantly decreased from 876 to 501m2/g and 1.13 to 0.26cm3/g respectively with increasing Nb contents of samples. This is attributed to the possible formation of small niobium oxides clusters in the mesoporous channels of SBA-15. Electron microscopy Scanning electron microscopy (SEM) images of Nb-SBA-15-40 sample are shown in Fig. 4 . This sample consisted of many rope-like domains (Fig. 4a, high magnification) with relatively uniform sizes of ∼3μm, which aggregated into wheat like macrostucture (Fig. 4b, low magnification). It agrees with the observation reported by Zhao et al. [35,41]. Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) image of the catalyst (Fig. 5 ) clearly demonstrates the retention of the periodic structure, which shows the highly ordered hexagonal arrangement of the channels. All show that the 2D hexagonal-ordered structure of Nb-SBA-15-40 was preserved well even at relatively high Nb contents. UV–vis DRS The UV–vis DRS and Raman spectra of Nb-SBA-15 samples and Nb2O5/SBA-15 are presented in Fig. 6 . Nb2O5/SBA-15 (the molar ratio of Si/Nb is 40) as a comparison was prepared by impregnation method. As shown in Fig. 6, all the Nb-SBA-15 samples show a band centered around 200nm and a broad shoulder centered around 250nm which are not presented in Nb2O5/SBA-15. The peak at 200nm is typically associated with Nb-O bonds, which is unambiguously assigned to the ligand-to-metal charge transfer transition in the NbO4 tetrahedra units [42]. It indicates that there is niobium in the silica framework for all the Nb-SBA-15 samples. This is consistent with the results of XRD analysis. The broad band centered around 250nm may be assigned to a low-energy charge transfer transition between the tetrahedral oxygen ligands and the central Nb ions in the mononuclear tetrahedral NbO4 [42]. It is interesting to note that the intensity of both the bands increases at first, and then decreases with increasing the doping of Nb content. Nb-SBA-15-40 sample has the maximum intensity of both bands. It shows that there are more niobium species which is in the silica framework and the mononuclear tetrahedral NbO4 in Nb-SBA-15-40 than in other Nb-SBA-15 samples. In contrast, a broad and strong peak around 315nm is presented in the spectrum of Nb2O5/SBA-15 sample. It may be assigned to large size Nb2O5 clusters in the mesoporous channels. The peak around 315nm is also observed in the spectra of Nb-SBA-15-20 and Nb-SBA-10 samples and the intensity of peak increases with increasing the doping of Nb content. It indicates that there are more large size Nb2O5 clusters in Nb-SBA-10 than that in Nb-SBA-20. Raman spectroscopy For more specific information about the nature of Nb atoms in the SBA-15 framework, Raman analysis was performed. It can be seen from Fig. 7 , for the Nb2O5/SBA-15 sample, that a strong Raman band is observed at ∼680cm−1 due to bulk Nb2O5 [43], indicating the presence of polymerized niobium oxide species on Nb2O5/SBA-15 surface. For the Nb-SBA-15 samples, the peak at ∼690cm−1 did not appear. A Raman band at ∼980cm−1 arises, which may be assigned to the NbO stretching mode of isolated surface NbO4 species [43]. The broad, weak band at ∼920cm−1, which is observed for Nb-SBA-15 samples, has been assigned to Si(O−)/Si(O−)2 functionality due to the formation of MOSi bonds [44]. It is suggested that there are niobium species incorporated silicate of MFI structure. The results are consistent with the UV–vis DRS analysis. NH3-TPD The acidity of the Nb-SBA-15 samples was determined by temperature-programmed desorption of ammonia. And the TPD profiles of these samples with different Si/Nb ratios are given in Fig. 8 . By comparing SBA-15 and Nb-SBA-15 samples, it was found that most acid sites were generated by the niobium incorporated in SBA-15 materials. All Nb-SBA-15 samples showed one low temperature peak, characterizing weak acid sites centered around 150–220°C. With decreasing the Si/Nb ratio (or increasing niobium contents) from 80 to 10, the total acidity of Nb-SBA-15 sample increased. It is further indicated that the acid sites formed during the post modification with niobium. Thus the amount of total acidity depended on the amount of niobium presented in the samples, but not increased linearly with the niobium contents of the samples. Pyridine-FTIR To investigate different types of acidic sites, the pyridine-FTIR spectra were collected. In Fig. 9 , the pyridine-FTIR spectra show that all Nb-SBA-15 samples had both Brønsted and Lewis acid sites. The bands at 1545cm−1 and 1445cm−1 matched Brønsted and Lewis acid sites respectively. The band at 1490cm−1 is attributed to the adsorption of pyridine on both Lewis and Brønsted acid sites. The acidic properties (type, strength and amount) of different Nb-SBA-15 samples were also studied by collecting pyridine-FTIR at different pyridine desorption temperature using the method proposed by Lachter et al. [36] and the data are recorded in Table 2 . It is found that the amount of Brønsted and Lewis acid sites increased with increasing the amount of niobium and Nb-SBA-15-10 sample had the highest acidic amount while Nb-SBA-15-80 had the lowest acidic amount, which agrees with the results of NH3-TPD. In Table 2, it could also be seen that with increasing niobium contents, the total Brønsted/Lewis acid ratio increased from 0.10 to 0.21. Nb-SBA-15-40 sample had a modest total amount of acid sites and Brønsted/Lewis acid ratio, corresponding to 95.5μmolg−1 and 0.17, respectively. Furthermore, the weak, medium and strong acid sites were defined as the ones which corresponding to evacuation at 100°C, 200°C and 400°C, respectively [45]. The amounts of different strength acidic sites are also calculated and present in Table 2. It shows that Nb-SBA-15 samples had a larger amount of weak and medium acid sites than strong acid sites. Catalytic activity To investigate the catalytic performance of Nb-SBA-15 catalysts with different Si/Nb ratios and the influence of acid sites on the reaction of dehydration of glucose, Experiments were carried out in a THF/H2O biphasic system and the results are summarized in Table 3 . Under the reaction conditions employed, all the catalysts gave high selectivity to HMF (∼50–65%), which was better than most catalysts reported. The maximum conversion of glucose can reach 97.8% over Nb-SBA-15-10. This indicated that the solid acid catalyst with more niobium content would promote the conversion of glucose. The selectivity to HMF changed with the Nb/Si ratios and Nb-SBA-15-40 catalyst gave a higher selectivity to HMF, which may be due to a higher Brønsted/Lewis acid ratio in Nb-SBA-15-40. The results are consistent with the previous reports [45,46], in which the high molar ratio of B/L acid ratio would promote the formation of HMF from glucose. However, the molar ratio of B/L increased further from 0.17 to 0.21 with the decrease of Si/Nb (20, 10) and the selectivity to HMF of corresponding Nb-SBA-15 worsened. This result conflicts with the previous reports [45,46]. Therefore, the L*/L (L*: strong Lewis acids) ratio were considered and shown in Table 2. It is interesting to find that the selectivity to HMF came down when L*/L ratio increased from 0.05 to 0.08 with increasing niobium content., The selectivity to HMF over Nb-SBA-15-40 catalyst (65.8%) is the highest followed by that of Nb-SBA-15-20 catalyst (56.9%) and that of Nb-SBA-15-10 catalyst (51.4%) in order. This indicates that the low L*/L acid ratio would promote the formation of HMF from glucose, which means B/L ratio and L*/L ratio are two factor shaving effect on the conversion of glucose to HMF. In other words, that is not to say that the higher B/L ratio or the lower L*/L ratio there was, a better selectivity to HMF would be obtained. The highest HMF yield of 65.8% was obtained over Nb-SBA-15-40 with 93.5% glucose conversion. The suitable amount of Lewis acid sites, B/L acid ratio and L*/L interacted with each other to gain the highest selectivity and yield to HMF. Further study on the active sites of Nb-SBA-15 in the conversion of glucose, Pyridine-FTIR and catalytic performance in glucose conversion of Nb2O5/SBA-15 sample is given (see Fig. 9, Tables 2 and 3). For Nb2O5/SBA-15 sample, niobium species mainly exists in the form of bulk niobium oxide. The acid strength and amount of Brønsted acid and Lewis acid are so low that the glucose conversion, selectivity to HMF and yield of HMF over it are low. For Nb-SBA-15 samples, the NbO4 units of the hydrated surface niobia species on silica might be connected by Nb-OH-Nb bridges [44]. Since the structures of the surface niobia species are reversible during hydration and dehydration, these niobium species exhibited a charater of Brønsted acid sites during glucose conversion in the aqueous solution. The Brønsted acid strength and amount of Nb-SBA-15 samples increased with increasing the doping of Nb. On the other hand, the niobium species which is in the silica framework and the mononuclear tetrahedral NbO4 can accept electron pairs to produce Lewis acid sites. Moreover, the niobium of the mononuclear tetrahedral NbO4 may be a kind of weak Lewis acid site due to the charge transfer between the tetrahedral oxygen ligands and the central Nb ions [42]. The results of UV–vis DRS show that there are more mononuclear tetrahedral NbO4 in Nb-SBA-15-40 than those in the other Nb-SBA-15 samples. So, Nb-SBA-15-40 sample has more weak Lewis acid sites and appropriate L*/L value and the best yields of HMF can be obtained over it in the glucose conversion reaction. The results suggest that weak Lewis acid sites participate in the isomerization of glucose to fructose and then the Brønsted acid sites convert the fructose into HMF, whereas strong Lewis acid sites result in the formation of undesired byproducts (such as humins) to reduce the HMF selectivity. Nb-SBA-15-40 catalyst was studied for the further optimization of reaction conditions. The effect of Nb-SBA-15-40 catalyst amount on glucose dehydration reaction was investigated and results are shown in Fig. 10 . It is observed that when the catalyst amount was increased from 0.03g to 0.10g, the conversion of glucose improved from 76.4% to 93.5% and the HMF selectivity also increased from 44.1% to 61.5%. However, more catalysts drove the reaction towards condensation, thus slightly decreasing the selectivity to HMF. When the catalyst amount climbed to 0.15g, glucose conversion increased slightly to 94.2% while the HMF selectivity dropped to 58.1%. To maximize HMF yield, the reaction temperature was further optimized. As shown in Fig. 11 a, reaction temperature had a pronounced effect on the glucose conversion reaction. At lower temperature, the glucose conversion rate was slow. The reaction rate was significantly enhanced with the temperature increase. However, HMF selectivity would be reduced when the temperature was raised from 165°C to 180°C (Fig. 11b). The highest HMF yield of 61.8% and selectivity of 65.8% were achieved when the reaction temperature was 165°C and reaction time was 3h as shown in Fig. 11b and c. The HMF yield had a slight drop as the reaction time was longer than 3h owing to the formation of condensation products of HMF. Conversion of cellulose to HMF We have also studied the conversion to HMF from cellulose, which is the most abundant renewable lignocellulosic biomass resource [47]. The process of HMF synthesis from cellulose is more complicated than from glucose, because the process from cellulose involves hydrolysis, isomerization and dehydration [48]. The process of HMF synthesis from cellulose needs a higher temperature and longer time. As clearly presented in Fig. 12 , to optimize the reaction condition, the influence of reaction time on the process was investigated. The first step is that cellulose hydrolyzed to glucose which is the rapid reaction. The yield of glucose reached the maximum 40.3% at 2h and the yield of HMF was only 17.8% from glucose. As the reaction time increased from 2h to 8h, the output of HMF increased while the amount of glucose decreased. When the reaction time exceeded 8h, the reaction solution became darker and the yield of HMF fell down. But no byproduct was detected by GC–MS and HPLC. Considering the formation of humins from cellulose goes through HMF intermediate specie, we think the drop of HMF yield is due to the formation of humins [49]. The effect of temperature with a reaction time of 8h was also studied and the result is shown in Fig. 13 . The yield of HMF reached the maximum 50.7% at 170°C. When the temperature was under 170°C, the conversion of cellulose cannot perform completely. However, when the temperature increased from 170°C to 190°C, the yield of HMF slowly decreased to 20.6%. It was found that the temperature affected the cellulose conversion in two opposite ways: On one hand, the conversion of cellulose was accelerated by increased temperature. On the other hand, the side reaction (HMF condensation) was also accelerated by raising temperature. Catalytic stability Heterogeneous catalysts that possess excellent hydrothermal stability are essential to the development of aqueous phase biomass processing. Niobium has the superiority of high hydrothermal stability and SBA-15 has the large pore which carbon deposition is not easy to happen in it [50], so it was speculated that Nb-SBA-15 should have the superior hydrothermal stability in aqueous solution. The used catalyst was washed with water and ethanol three times respectively, dried and used for the next cycle. Here, the reaction time (1.5h) which gives the glucose conversion of ∼60%, is chosen as the reaction time to test the catalytic stability of Nb-SBA-15-40 catalyst in glucose conversion. The recycle test results of Nb-SBA-15-40 are shown in Fig. 14 . After being used for 10 times, the glucose conversion and HMF yield were still kept at 56.1% and 32.3%, respectively, which indicated the catalyst can be recycled effectively up to 10 cycles without much loss in catalytic activity. TEM images of the Nb-SBA-15-40 samples before and after glucose dehydration reaction were taken as shown in Fig. 15 . It shows that the integrity of the mesoporous structure of Nb-SBA-15-40 was retained after reaction. The results also show the feasibility of Nb-SBA-15 catalysts for dehydration of saccharides. Conclusions The Nb-SBA-15 catalyst we synthesized is an effective catalyst for the production of HMF from carbohydrate. The effect of Si/Nb ratio on the catalytic activity and selectivity of Nb-SBA-15 catalysts was systematically investigated. It was found that the acid distribution, strength and concentration on Nb-SBA-15 would be variable with Si/Nb ratios of Nb-SBA-15 samples. The NbO4 units of the hydrated surface niobia species on silica might be connected by Nb-OH-Nb bridges and exhibit the role of Brønsted acid sites during glucose conversion in the aqueous solution. On the other hand, the niobium in the silica framework and the mononuclear tetrahedral NbO4 can accept electron pairs. Especially the mononuclear tetrahedral NbO4 may be weak Lewis acid sites due to the charge transfer between the tetrahedral oxygen ligands and the central Nb ions. Since Nb-SBA-15-40 has more niobium species in the SBA-15 silica framework and more mononuclear tetrahedral NbO4, Nb-SBA-15-40 catalyst exihibited suitable amount of Lewis acid site, Brønsted/Lewis acid ratio and L*/L ratio, which interacted with each other and gave the highest HMF selectivity and yield among the Nb-SBA-15 catalysts. In glucose conversion, the yield of HMF can reach 61.8% in the biphasic condition with THF/H2O-NaCl. In cellulose conversion, the HMF yield can attain 50.7%. Moreover, Nb-SBA-15-40 catalyst could recycle for 10 times at 165°C without losing its catalytic activity and selectivity. coredata.dc:description: 5-hydroxymethyl furfural (HMF) is a bio-based platform chemical with high potential. The as-synthesized Nb-SBA-15 catalysts with mesoporous structures showed high catalytic performance for the conversion of carbohydrates to HMF in a “one-pot” process using biphasic conditions of THF/H2O-NaCl as the solvents. Nb-SBA-15 catalysts with different Si/Nb ratios were characterized by analytical techniques such as XRD, elemental analysis, SEM, TEM, N2 adsorption, NH3-TPD UV–vis DRS, Raman and Pyridine-FTIR. It was found that the acidity of Nb-SBA-15 catalysts could be tuned by modifying addition amount of niobium. The effects of reaction conditions, including temperature, time, and catalyst loading, on the conversions of carbohydrates and the yields of HMF were also investigated. The studies showed that Nb-SBA-15-40 catalysts which Si/Nb ratio is 40 gave the best yields of HMF due that Nb-SBA-15-40 had more niobium species in the SBA-15 silica framework and the mononuclear tetrahedral NbO4. Under the optimized conditions, the yield of HMF could reach 61.8% at 93.5% glucose conversion and 50.7% at 94.0% cellulose conversion, respectively. Moreover, its catalytic performance was largely retained after 10 recycles in glucose conversion reaction vindicating its good catalytic stability.
coredata.dc:title: Hydrothermally stable Nb-SBA-15 catalysts applied in carbohydrate conversion to 5-hydroxymethyl furfural
